learnings.title: Visual Hierarchy and Typography
learnings.bodyMd:
# Visual Hierarchy and Typography

## Overview
Establish a clean hierarchy with consistent typography to improve scanability and focus.

## Key Concepts
- Hierarchy: title, subtitle, body, annotations.
- Fonts: 1–2 families; 3 sizes max.
- Alignment and whitespace for rhythm.

## Examples
- Left‑aligned text blocks, consistent margins.
- Larger slide titles with concise headlines.

## Common Pitfalls
- Too many fonts and sizes.
- Dense blocks without breathing room.

## Summary
Keep type simple and consistent. Use whitespace as a design element to guide the eye.

learnings.title: Chart Integrity and Minimalism
learnings.bodyMd:
# Chart Integrity and Minimalism

## Overview
Remove chartjunk, keep scales honest, and let the data tell the story.

## Key Concepts
- Honest axes and baselines.
- Minimalism: gridlines, labels, legend placement.
- Color usage: few hues; consistent mapping.

## Examples
- Direct labeling instead of legends.
- Avoid 3D and decorative effects.

## Common Pitfalls
- Truncated axes that mislead.
- Over‑coloring many series.

## Summary
Use clean, truthful charts with minimal decoration and clear labels to emphasize signal over noise.

learnings.title: Templates, Grids, and Consistency
learnings.bodyMd:
# Templates, Grids, and Consistency

## Overview
Lock in a slide grid and template to maintain visual consistency and speed.

## Key Concepts
- Grid systems: column guides for alignment.
- Master slides: title, content, comparison, appendix.
- Tokens: colors, spacing, icon styles.

## Examples
- Reuse master layouts and spacing variables.
- Global color mapping for categories.

## Common Pitfalls
- Ad‑hoc layouts that shift between slides.
- Inconsistent color meanings.

## Summary
Adopt a grid and template to reduce variance and keep attention on content, not formatting.

learnings.title: Highlighting Data and Annotations
learnings.bodyMd:
# Highlighting Data and Annotations

## Overview
Guide attention with minimal color, clear callouts, and direct labels on key points.

## Key Concepts
- Color as emphasis, not decoration.
- Callouts: arrows, notes, and highlight bands.
- Pre‑attentive attributes: color, size, position.

## Examples
- Highlight just one series and mute the rest.
- Annotate deltas on bars/lines directly.

## Common Pitfalls
- Rainbow palettes that distract.
- Legends that force constant eye travel.

## Summary
Use a restrained palette and direct annotations to make the insight pop instantly.

learnings.title: Accessibility and Inclusive Design
learnings.bodyMd:
# Accessibility and Inclusive Design

## Overview
Design slides that work for color blindness, small screens, and screen readers.

## Key Concepts
- Contrast ratios and color‑blind safe palettes.
- Alt text for images; descriptive titles.
- Font sizes and touch‑target spacing.

## Examples
- Use color plus shape/label for encodings.
- Provide alt text and descriptive captions.

## Common Pitfalls
- Relying on color alone.
- Tiny text that fails at distance.

## Summary
Inclusive design broadens comprehension and participation. Build accessibility into your slide system from the start.
